bestBHT.bht: Be in readiness for the master's return at the wedding feast. Let your loins be girded in preparation, as people in the East would tuck up their long garments for travel or labor. Keep your lamps burning, whether referring to the Scriptures guiding your ministry or the brightness of your profession, shining before others to glorify God. Immerse yourself in the teachings of the Gospel, abiding faithfully and never fading, just as servants carry lights at night weddings.

Henry Alford: The main thought here only is that He is away at a feast, and will return.
But in the background lies the wedding in all its truth—not brought out here, but elsewhere.
Let your loins be girded, your lights.
Jamieson-Fausset-Brown: loins . . . girded—to fasten up the long outer garment, always done before travel and work.
The meaning is, Be in readiness.
Philip Schaff: Let your loins be girded about. Unless the long garments of the Orientals were thus girt up, it was impossible to walk or to serve at table.
And your lamps burning, i.e., in readiness for the master returning at night. Be in continual readiness to receive the returning Messiah, your master, as befits your relation to Him.
The first figure points to the activity, the second to the watchfulness, of the faithful servant.
Archibald T. Robertson: Be girded about...to fasten the garments with a girdle.
John Gill: Let your loins be girded about... keeping close to the doctrines of the Gospel, abiding faithfully by them, even unto death... denotes readiness for business.

Your lights burning... may design either the Scriptures of truth, which were to be a light or lamp unto them, guiding and directing them in the ministration of the Gospel; or the lamps of profession, which should be kept clear and bright... that should so shine before men, that all may see them, and glorify God.
The allusion is to persons waiting at a wedding in the night, with torches and flambeaus in their hands.
John Wesley: Let your loins be girt - An allusion to the long garments...
...worn by the eastern nations, which they girded or tucked up about their loins, when they journeyed or were employed in any labour...
...as also to the lights that servants used to carry at weddings, which were generally in the night.

bhtAttempts.bht: Be in readiness, for the master is away at a feast and will return. Though not explicitly mentioned, the background of a wedding is implied, where the faithful servant must be prepared. Like fastening up the long outer garment before travel or work, let your loins be girded about in readiness for the tasks ahead. Just as servants at a wedding keep their lamps burning, be in continual readiness to receive the returning Messiah. May your activity and watchfulness reflect your faithful service to the master.

Be in readiness, for the master is away at a feast and will return. Let your loins be girded about in readiness, like fastening up the long outer garment before travel or work. Keep your lamps burning, in continual readiness to receive the returning Messiah. Your activity and watchfulness should reflect your faithful service to the master at all times. Do not waiver, but stay committed to the doctrines of the Gospel and let your light shine brightly so that others may see and glorify God.

Be in readiness for the master's return at the wedding feast. Let your loins be girded in preparation, as people in the East would tuck up their long garments for travel or labor. Keep your lamps burning, whether referring to the Scriptures guiding your ministry or the brightness of your profession, shining before others to glorify God. Immerse yourself in the teachings of the Gospel, abiding faithfully and never fading, just as servants carry lights at night weddings.

Be prepared for the master's return at the wedding feast. Let your loins be girded, fastening up your garments for readiness, as people in the East would do before travel or work. Keep your lamps burning, whether referring to the light of Scripture guiding your ministry or the brightness of your profession, shining before others. Stay faithful to the teachings of the Gospel, never wavering, like servants carrying torches at night weddings. Be in constant readiness, for the master will surely come.

Be prepared for the master's return at the wedding feast. Let your loins be girded, fastening up your garments for readiness, as people in the East would do before travel or work. Keep your lamps burning, whether referring to the light of Scripture guiding your ministry or the brightness of your profession. Stay faithful to the teachings of the Gospel, never wavering, like servants carrying torches at night weddings. Be in constant readiness, for the master will surely come.
